content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A group of students wish to experimentally determine a nonideal battery’s internal resistance <math alttext="R sub lowercase i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. The students have various resistors of different resistances, all unknown, as well as wires, voltmeters, and ammeters that can all be considered to be ideal.(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine <math alttext="R sub lowercase i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A group of students wish to experimentally determine a nonideal battery’s internal resistance <math alttext="R sub lowercase i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. The students have various resistors of different resistances, all unknown, as well as wires, voltmeters, and ammeters that can all be considered to be ideal.(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine <math alttext="R sub lowercase i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be used to determine <math alttext="R sub lowercase i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>.

Next, the students are asked to determine the resistivity of a material. They are given several wires made with the material that all have the same length <math alttext="L equals 10.00 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10.00</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>, but different diameters. The students connect each wire, one at a time, across the nonideal battery from part (a). They measure the diameter <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math>, and current <math alttext="uppercase I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> for each wire, producing the data shown in the table.<math alttext="D, in millimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>mm</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="delta V, in volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="uppercase I, in amps" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="0.200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.200</mn></math><math alttext="3.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.00</mn></math><math alttext="0.14" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.14</mn></math><math alttext="0.240" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.240</mn></math><math alttext="2.99" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.99</mn></math><math alttext="0.21" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.21</mn></math><math alttext="0.320" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.320</mn></math><math alttext="2.92" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.92</mn></math><math alttext="0.38" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.38</mn></math><math alttext="0.440" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.440</mn></math><math alttext="2.93" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.93</mn></math><math alttext="0.70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.70</mn></math><math alttext="0.500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.500</mn></math><math alttext="2.85" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.85</mn></math><math alttext="0.89" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.89</mn></math>Note: Wire length <math alttext="L equals 10.00 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10.00</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>(c)i. Indicate what quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for the resistivity of the wire material.Horizontal axis: __________ Vertical axis: __________Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the grid provided, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii), calculate an experimental value for the resistivity of the wire material.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
